posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked:
For the off season, we decided to switch to Swerve in contrast to the regular tank drive.  It has been a delight using swerve, however we have encountered a problem with the path planning. Whenever we map out the robot to stop right behind the leave line on the Crescendo map, it doesn’t stop at all, and all motors run full power backwards, as seen in the video below. I’m not sure what is going on, as our plybot swerve before this had no issues at all with pathplanning. Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

Google Drive file.

If code is needed to tackle this situation, please let me know and I will upload the updated swerve code on GitHub. Thank you in advance.
Code is needed. Sounds like it could be a mirroring problem though, can’t say for sure without code

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked:
Here is a link to the github repository

GitHub - team5863/RedStickSwerve: Swerve Drive Robot code for 2024 Redstick Rumble... Swerve Drive Robot code for 2024 Redstick Rumble Competition

Swerve Drive Robot code for 2024 Redstick Rumble Competition

link_counts.title: GitHub - team5863/RedStickSwerve: Swerve Drive Robot code for 2024 Redstick Rumble Competition

posts.name: Aditya Gajula
posts.cooked:
I would recommend adjusting the heading.

I am yet to test some PathPlanner paths on our swerve tomorrow, but setting the heading to 180 for both the starting pose & ending pose for the path (not the auto, but the individual path) back from the note to the speaker seemed to ensure that the robot stopped where it was supposed to on PathPlanner.

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: Thank you!  I will have my team give this a try!  Yesterday we re-zeroed the encoders, confirmed all CAN id’s and flipped “front” and “back” because we noticed our gyro was oriented opposite to what we assigned front and back (maybe grasping, but we are at a complete loss here).  We appreciate any and all suggestions!

posts.name: Aditya Gajula
posts.cooked:
Also, I cloned your repo and checked the path on PathPlanner. I set the endpoint heading as 180.0 for the OneNoteLeave path and the robot seems to be stopping right at the speaker and not go behind it (image below).

I’ll check in again after testing our PathPlanner paths on our robot today, just to make sure my understanding about the “heading” variable is correct. The definition of “heading” in the PathPlanner docs is - “The heading, or direction of travel, of the robot while passing through this point in degrees.”

So, I’m assuming that adjusting the heading won’t turn the robot’s direction or change the yaw angle as rotation targets are a separate thing for that. image 2526×1424 187 KB

image 2526×1424 187 KB

image 2526×1424 187 KB

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: I can’t thank you enough!

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: We tried changing the starting and ending pose to 180 but it is still doing the same thing.

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked:
On further testing we were able to get it to work by doing what you said of changing the poses to 180. We deleted the path and auto and made a new one that was the exact same and it worked. We had tried that before with no success, so we don’t know why it worked this time. Although, it doesn’t make sense that we have to put the starting pose as 180 when the robot is actually starting at 0, so if you have any idea of why its that way it would be a big help.

Edit: We were able to fix the issue and now the robot actually travels in the right direction along the path. Turns out our drive motors needed to be inverted. However, the robot is now moving way to fast along the path, overshooting, and not driving perfectly straight. PID likely needs to be tuned which is what we will try. I will update if that works or doesn’t.

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: Thank you everyone that has helped us.  I think we have ths issue fixed, BUT we cannot test it because we have now lost all communiucation with our robot!  Shuffleboard went down, when redeployed, it’s telling us that there are no values from the code.  We cannot access our sendable chooser and cannot see our module positions. We have changed rio, wifi and PDH , we deploy code but the robot does not seem to get it.  Completely inoperable!  We have an event this weekend and are completely stumped.  Anyone have any input?  Thank you again!

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: What do you mean when the robot doesn’t get the code? Is it that code deploys successfully but driver station dosent show robot code as active?

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: Yes, we deploy the code, but the shuffleboard doesn’t show any values (acutally it only is showing values for our limelight.  All other fields have disappeared).  When they press ANY button on their controllers, nothing happens.  It was really wierd.  It was working fine, they called me to show me, and when I walked into the room shuffleboard when blank and they have not been able to make the robot move since.

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: We are now wondering if we could have some corrupt files?

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: Have you tried restarting the roborio? If that doesn’t work, try reimaging it. If this dosent fix the issue, there could be a software bug that keeps crashing the robot code.

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: I’m not sure.  We did try 2 different robo rios with the same results, so I’m leaning towards something crashing the code.  I will have them try restarting the rio and reimaging it.  We are also going to try deploying a new simple code to it running just one motor and see if that works.  My thought is that if there’s a line of code that was corrupted during the many iterations they did trying to get path planner to work, the new code should work and then they get to find what they corrupted in their code.  I’m just hoping that’s the problem and we can get it fixed today.  Thanks for the input, and we are still open to anything anyone else has to offer!

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: Do you have a stacktrace in your riolog?

link_counts.title: Reading Stacktraces — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: There is no stacktrace or any errors in the rio log.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
It might be helpful if you posted a screen shot of your Driver Station open to the Diagnostics Tab .

You might also try access the roboRIO Web Dashboard

link_counts.title: FRC Driver Station Powered by NI LabVIEW — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
roboRIO Web Dashboard — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: k.gill
posts.cooked: We figured out the issue. Turns out the line of code that creates an instance of RobotContainer in Robot.java got deleted by accident at some point during testing. Thank you for your help though!
